goals: To develop academic writing skills for humanities & social sciences
To learn to make use of databases for research in humanities & social sciences
To develop oral presentation skills in academic contexts
syllabus:
**_Academic Writing & Oral Presentation Skills for Humanity Disciplines & Social Sciences_** **(Fall 2021)**

**Instructor**: Miao-Hsia Chang  **E-mail**: [mhchang@ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:mhchang@ntnu.edu.tw)

**Classroom:** Chin Building 302; **Office hours:** Tue 12:00-14:00; Wed. 13:10-15:10; or by appointment

A. Course Description
=====================

              The primary goal of this class is to enhance students’ development of the academic writing, research methods, and presentation skills in soft and hard sciences, especially in social sciences and humanities disciplines. Students will develop the English reading and writing skills necessary to comprehend and produce journal articles and/or theses/dissertations in their specialized field. Students will also discuss and develop the skills they will need to present their research in a seminar or at an international conference.

**C. Textbooks**

Swales, John M. & Christine B. Feak. 3rd ed. 2012.  Academic Writing for Graduate Students: Essential Tasks and Skills (AWGS). Ann Arbor: The University of Michigan Press.

Glasman-Deal, H. (2010). _Science Research Writing for Non-Native Speakers of English_ (**SRWR)**. London: Imperial College Press. (Available for download from NTNU library)

**D. Requirements and Grading Policy:**   

Presentation: 25%

Participation: 25%

Writing assignments and their revisions: 50%

methodologies.note: Lectures on aspects of academic writing, style, rhetorical issues, and strategies in academic writing
Tasks based learning about problems in examples of academci writing and their possible solutions
Collaboration among peers to enhance writing skills
Where necessary, materials related to a particular field of study under discussion will be brought to the classroom
Project-based research and writing on a topic related to the discipline to which a given student belongs to

grading.note: Writing of different sections in term papers/journal articles/theses
Discussion and presentation of writing skills; Peer editing and evaluation of writing assignments
Presentation of principles of different sections in academic writing, correponding examples, and useful expressions
